The product $R\sin\theta$ is a measure of how well a bundle of rays can be collected and directly gives the minimum radius of a disk that this bundle can be focused onto. 

In general the angular spread of fast electrons will depend on many parameters, such as the laser intensity or the laser contrast ratio. Green et al \cite{Green:2008} compared experimental data with other results published in the literature and concluded that the angular spread increases with laser intensity. This means that, assuming a fixed power of the laser beam, the angular spread of fast electrons increases as the beam radius decreases. Thus, the beam radius and the angular spread are competing factors in an attempt to minimise $R'_{\text{min}}$ and it is not a priori clear whether a small spot size coupled with a large angular spread is better than a large spot size coupled with a small angular spread.
